content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: Technologiestiftung Berlin, dirname: hackingboxgoes, projectname: Hacking Box goes CityLAB, projectsubline: Technologiestiftung Berlin, headlineintro: Worum geht es?, contentintro: Wir öffnen die Blackboxes der smarten Alltagsgeräte und zeigen, dass man mit digitaler Hardware kreativ und selbstbestimmt umgehen kann. Dazu verleihen wir in Berlin und dem Umland individuell zusammengestellte Hardwareboxen für Schulprojekte, Workshops, Seminare, Hackathons & Co und beraten in der Planung eigener Hardwareprojekte. Außerdem stellen wir exemplarische Anwendungsbeispiele zu aktuellen Themen der digitalen Stadtgesellschaft zur Verfügung. Mit dem Umzug der Ausleihe der Hacking Box ins CityLAB haben wir ein permanentes Angebot für die Community vor Ort geschaffen und tragen entsprechend zu Ausbau und Vernetzung bei., headlineblockone: Was ist schon passiert?, contentblockone: Im letzten Jahr haben wir wieder einige neue Ausleiher*innen im CityLAB begrüßen dürfen, welche ihr digitales Angebot mit Hilfe der Hacking Box ausbauen konnten. So etwa die Stadtbibliothek Treptow-Köpenick, welche im Rahmen ihrer „Digitalen Bildungswochen“ unsere Anleitung zum Bau einer Gießanlage samt Hardware für die Gestaltung eines Workshops nutzte. Oder die Studentinnen des Studiengangs Arbeitslehre an der TU Berlin, welche eine interaktive Ernährungspyramide bauten, die beim Berühren von bestimmten Obst- und Gemüsesorten (oder auch Süßigkeiten) vorher aufgenommene Texte mit Informationen zum Nährwert abspielt. Außerdem diente die Hacking Box als Enabler in einigen unserer Workshops, so etwa bei „Prototype Your Future City!“. Wir wünschen uns, dass die Bandbreite dieser und anderer Beispiele potenzielle Nutzer ermutigt, eigene digitale Formate zu entwickeln., headlineblocktwo: Wie kann ich mitmachen?, contentblocktwo: Informiere dich auf unserer Microsite über die Hacking Box, welche Projekte sich damit umsetzen lassen und natürlich, wie du sie dir ausleihen kannst! Neuigkeiten zu Projekten rund um die Hacking Box dokumentieren wir auch auf dem Blog der Technologiestiftung. Gern geben wir die Erfahrungen der letzten Jahre aus dem Projekt weiter und zeigen, wie sich der materielle Aufwand für Hardware in Grenzen halten lässt. Und wer weiß – vielleicht entstehen daraus weitere Ausleihanfragen in Berlin, der nächste Hackathon oder die brandneue Coding-AG an deiner Schule!? Sprich uns gern an., headlineblockthree: Kontakt:, contentblockthree: Carolin Clausnitzer , link: https://www.technologiestiftung-berlin.de/de/hackingbox/

gsx$contentintro.$t: Wir öffnen die Blackboxes der smarten Alltagsgeräte und zeigen, dass man mit digitaler Hardware kreativ und selbstbestimmt umgehen kann. Dazu verleihen wir in Berlin und dem Umland individuell zusammengestellte Hardwareboxen für Schulprojekte, Workshops, Seminare, Hackathons & Co und beraten in der Planung eigener Hardwareprojekte. Außerdem stellen wir exemplarische Anwendungsbeispiele zu aktuellen Themen der digitalen Stadtgesellschaft zur Verfügung. Mit dem Umzug der Ausleihe der Hacking Box ins CityLAB haben wir ein permanentes Angebot für die Community vor Ort geschaffen und tragen entsprechend zu Ausbau und Vernetzung bei.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: Im letzten Jahr haben wir wieder einige neue Ausleiher*innen im CityLAB begrüßen dürfen, welche ihr digitales Angebot mit Hilfe der Hacking Box ausbauen konnten. So etwa die Stadtbibliothek Treptow-Köpenick, welche im Rahmen ihrer „Digitalen Bildungswochen“ unsere Anleitung zum Bau einer Gießanlage samt Hardware für die Gestaltung eines Workshops nutzte. Oder die Studentinnen des Studiengangs Arbeitslehre an der TU Berlin, welche eine interaktive Ernährungspyramide bauten, die beim Berühren von bestimmten Obst- und Gemüsesorten (oder auch Süßigkeiten) vorher aufgenommene Texte mit Informationen zum Nährwert abspielt. Außerdem diente die Hacking Box als Enabler in einigen unserer Workshops, so etwa bei „Prototype Your Future City!“. Wir wünschen uns, dass die Bandbreite dieser und anderer Beispiele potenzielle Nutzer ermutigt, eigene digitale Formate zu entwickeln.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Informiere dich auf unserer Microsite über die Hacking Box, welche Projekte sich damit umsetzen lassen und natürlich, wie du sie dir ausleihen kannst! Neuigkeiten zu Projekten rund um die Hacking Box dokumentieren wir auch auf dem Blog der Technologiestiftung. Gern geben wir die Erfahrungen der letzten Jahre aus dem Projekt weiter und zeigen, wie sich der materielle Aufwand für Hardware in Grenzen halten lässt. Und wer weiß – vielleicht entstehen daraus weitere Ausleihanfragen in Berlin, der nächste Hackathon oder die brandneue Coding-AG an deiner Schule!? Sprich uns gern an.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Carolin Clausnitzer

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: lifecycle, projectname: Life_Cycle(), projectsubline: CityLAB Summer School 2019, projectsubsubline: Christian Larsen & Kevin Sarwas, headlineintro: Worum geht es?, contentintro: Das Ziel ist es Unfälle in unklaren oder schwer einsehbaren Abbiegesituationen zu vermeiden. Das kompakte und günstige System dient dabei als stationär installierter Abbiegeassistent. Abbiegende Fahrzeuge werden vor einfahrenden Radfahrer*innen gewarnt und können so rechtzeitig reagieren. Dabei kann Life_Cycle() aufgrund der Machine Vision Fähigkeiten (Objekt Detektierung und Objekt Klassifizierung) zwischen Verkehrsteilnehmenden unterscheiden und nur dann warnen wenn die Gefahr eines Aufpralls besteht., headlineblockone: Nächste Schritte?, contentblockone: Das Projekt ist mit dem Ende des Jahres ausgelaufen. Ein Prototyp der Grundlegenden Technologie kann in der Ausstellung des CityLab betrachtet werden. Das Projekt OpenTrafficCount basiert auf der gleichen Technologie (OpenDataCam vom MooveLab) wie Life_Cycle(). Das System kann möglicherweise als Add-On in den laufenden Betrieb des Forschungsprojektes mit eingebunden werden., headlineblocktwo: Wer ist beteiligt?, contentblocktwo: Life_Cycle() ist ein Projekt von Christian Larsen und Kevin Sarwas und ist im Rahmen der City Lab Summer School 2019 entstanden. Die Anschlussförderung wurde durch die Technologie Stiftung organisiert. Die Grundlegende Technologie und Hardware wurde vom Team MoveLab bereitgestellt., headlineblockthree: Kontakt:, contentblockthree: Christian Larsen und Kevin Serwas, link: https://github.com/cjlarswim/life_cycle

gsx$contentintro.$t: Das Ziel ist es Unfälle in unklaren oder schwer einsehbaren Abbiegesituationen zu vermeiden. Das kompakte und günstige System dient dabei als stationär installierter Abbiegeassistent. Abbiegende Fahrzeuge werden vor einfahrenden Radfahrer*innen gewarnt und können so rechtzeitig reagieren. Dabei kann Life_Cycle() aufgrund der Machine Vision Fähigkeiten (Objekt Detektierung und Objekt Klassifizierung) zwischen Verkehrsteilnehmenden unterscheiden und nur dann warnen wenn die Gefahr eines Aufpralls besteht.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: Das Projekt ist mit dem Ende des Jahres ausgelaufen. Ein Prototyp der Grundlegenden Technologie kann in der Ausstellung des CityLab betrachtet werden. Das Projekt OpenTrafficCount basiert auf der gleichen Technologie (OpenDataCam vom MooveLab) wie Life_Cycle(). Das System kann möglicherweise als Add-On in den laufenden Betrieb des Forschungsprojektes mit eingebunden werden.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Life_Cycle() ist ein Projekt von Christian Larsen und Kevin Sarwas und ist im Rahmen der City Lab Summer School 2019 entstanden. Die Anschlussförderung wurde durch die Technologie Stiftung organisiert. Die Grundlegende Technologie und Hardware wurde vom Team MoveLab bereitgestellt.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Christian Larsen und Kevin Serwas

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: aiforberlin, projectname: AI for Berlin, projectsubline: CityLAB (ein Projekt der Technologiestiftung Berlin)/Birds on Mars, headlineintro: Worum es geht?, contentintro: In den letzten Jahren konnte man das Potenzial von KI-Technologien in ganz unterschiedlichen Bereichen zeigen und teilweise die Fähigkeiten des Menschen deutlich überbieten. Da wir gerade in urbanen Räumen vor besonders großen Herausforderungen - und Chancen - stehen, wollen wir in einer lang angelegten Workshopreihe einen möglichen Nutzen der KI für Berlin finden und in reale, nachhaltige Umsetzungsprojekte bringen. Dabei steht neben der technischen Seite immer auch die Interdisziplinarität und Neugierde im Vordergrund., headlineblockone: Nächste Schritte?, contentblockone: Nachdem im ersten Workshop (November 2019) Ideen gesammelt und priorisiert wurden, werden im zweiten Teil (3. März 2020) ca. 3 Ideen hinsichtlich ihrer Umsetzbarkeit und Umsetzung weiterentwickelt. Dafür begeben wir uns z.B. auf die Suche nach Datentöpfen, Modellen, Erfolgsfaktoren und Ansprechpartner*innen. In weiteren Workshops werden daraus Prototypen und immer wieder werden weitere Iterationsschleifen zur Verbesserung gedreht, bis wir einen nachweisbaren Nutzen für Berlin erreicht haben., headlineblocktwo: Wie kann ich mitmachen?, contentblocktwo: Einfach über die Webseite anmelden. Programmiererfahrung und / oder Daten- und KI-Expertise sind super, aber kein Muss. Für uns steht interdisziplinäres Arbeiten immer auch im Vordergrund!, headlineblockthree: Kontakt:, contentblockthree: Nadine Riede, Florian Dohmann (Birds on Mars)

gsx$projectsubline.$t: CityLAB (ein Projekt der Technologiestiftung Berlin)/Birds on Mars

gsx$contentintro.$t: In den letzten Jahren konnte man das Potenzial von KI-Technologien in ganz unterschiedlichen Bereichen zeigen und teilweise die Fähigkeiten des Menschen deutlich überbieten. Da wir gerade in urbanen Räumen vor besonders großen Herausforderungen - und Chancen - stehen, wollen wir in einer lang angelegten Workshopreihe einen möglichen Nutzen der KI für Berlin finden und in reale, nachhaltige Umsetzungsprojekte bringen. Dabei steht neben der technischen Seite immer auch die Interdisziplinarität und Neugierde im Vordergrund.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: Nachdem im ersten Workshop (November 2019) Ideen gesammelt und priorisiert wurden, werden im zweiten Teil (3. März 2020) ca. 3 Ideen hinsichtlich ihrer Umsetzbarkeit und Umsetzung weiterentwickelt. Dafür begeben wir uns z.B. auf die Suche nach Datentöpfen, Modellen, Erfolgsfaktoren und Ansprechpartner*innen. In weiteren Workshops werden daraus Prototypen und immer wieder werden weitere Iterationsschleifen zur Verbesserung gedreht, bis wir einen nachweisbaren Nutzen für Berlin erreicht haben.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Einfach über die Webseite anmelden. Programmiererfahrung und / oder Daten- und KI-Expertise sind super, aber kein Muss. Für uns steht interdisziplinäres Arbeiten immer auch im Vordergrund!

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Nadine Riede, Florian Dohmann (Birds on Mars)

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: urbancare, projectname: Urban Care, projectsubline: Building Health Lab, headlineintro: Worum es geht?, contentintro: Mit der webbasierten Plattform UrbanCare vom Building Health Lab soll die Lebensqualität in den Stadtvierteln durch eine fußgängerfreundliche Infrastruktur verbessert werden. Die Plattform soll Entscheidungsträger*innen direkt auf die lokalen Hindernisse für Fußgänger*innen hinweisen und die Verbesserung begleiten. , headlineblockone: Was ist das Ziel?, contentblockone: Die Open-Government-Plattform UrbanCare ermöglicht 1) den Bürger*innen, Hindernisse für Fußgänger*innen zu identifizieren und aufzuzeigen, 2) der Industrie, klimafreundliche und sozial integrative Lösungen anzubieten, und 3) der Verwaltung eine effiziente Planung und Verwaltung der Bauprojekte. , headlineblocktwo: Nächste Schritte? , contentblocktwo: Aktuell erarbeiten wir das Feinkonzept und entwickeln mit Programmierer*innen und UX-Designer*innen eine benutzerfreundliche, interaktive digitale Plattform. Als nächster Schritt ist die Programmierung der Plattform mit einem Testlauf in einem der Berliner Stadtteile geplant. Dabei werden die Verwaltung und die Interessengruppen eingebunden, um für alle Nutzer das bestmögliche Ergebnis zu erzielen. Jeder wird dazu eingeladen, in der Nachbarschaft die wichtigsten Hindernisse und Verbesserungspotentiale für mehr Fußgängerfreundlichkeit aufzuzeigen. , headlineblockthree: Kontakt:, contentblockthree: info@buildinghealth.eu, Building Health Website

gsx$contentintro.$t: Mit der webbasierten Plattform UrbanCare vom Building Health Lab soll die Lebensqualität in den Stadtvierteln durch eine fußgängerfreundliche Infrastruktur verbessert werden. Die Plattform soll Entscheidungsträger*innen direkt auf die lokalen Hindernisse für Fußgänger*innen hinweisen und die Verbesserung begleiten.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: Die Open-Government-Plattform UrbanCare ermöglicht 1) den Bürger*innen, Hindernisse für Fußgänger*innen zu identifizieren und aufzuzeigen, 2) der Industrie, klimafreundliche und sozial integrative Lösungen anzubieten, und 3) der Verwaltung eine effiziente Planung und Verwaltung der Bauprojekte.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Aktuell erarbeiten wir das Feinkonzept und entwickeln mit Programmierer*innen und UX-Designer*innen eine benutzerfreundliche, interaktive digitale Plattform. Als nächster Schritt ist die Programmierung der Plattform mit einem Testlauf in einem der Berliner Stadtteile geplant. Dabei werden die Verwaltung und die Interessengruppen eingebunden, um für alle Nutzer das bestmögliche Ergebnis zu erzielen. Jeder wird dazu eingeladen, in der Nachbarschaft die wichtigsten Hindernisse und Verbesserungspotentiale für mehr Fußgängerfreundlichkeit aufzuzeigen.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: info@buildinghealth.eu, Building Health Website

content.$t:
defaultimg: FALSE, featured: TRUE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: giessdenkiez, projectname: Gieß den Kiez, projectsubline: CityLAB (a Technologiestiftung Berlin project), headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Gieß den Kiez is a platform to coordinate the irrigation of Berlin trees. The map shows almost all trees in Berlin with individual information such as water demand, age and species and invites all citizens to participate in the irrigation of our endangered tree population. Citizens can inform themselves about the water demand of trees in their neighbourhood, mark when they have watered and how much and "subscribe" to trees., headlineblockone: The functions at a glance , contentblockone: Overview of the Berlin tree population: 625,000 Berlin street and plant trees are visualized on an interactive map.

Exploration of the tree population: For each tree, information on type, age and estimated required water quantity is stored, so that more can be learned about each tree with the help of search and filter functions.

Watering and subscribing to trees: The platform shows which trees need how much water, depending on their age and urban maintenance. Users* can indicate when they last watered a tree. Trees can also be subscribed to if someone wants to water them regularly. This allows other people in the vicinity to see which trees need their attention.

Precipitation overview: With the help of daily updated data from the German Weather Service, it is possible to display for each tree how much rainwater it has received in the last 30 days.

Further information: In addition, the platform contains a wealth of useful information on correct irrigation and tree population, as well as relevant links and contact addresses. , headlineblocktwo: How can I participate?, contentblocktwo: You can simply register, water and mark the irrigation online. In addition, we will collect feedback over the next few months and consider further development of the first prototype. For the exchange with us and other interested people there is a public Slack channel , headlineblockthree: Contact, contentblockthree: Mirko Hohmann
Giessdenkiez.de
Slack channel

gsx$contentintro.$t: Gieß den Kiez is a platform to coordinate the irrigation of Berlin trees. The map shows almost all trees in Berlin with individual information such as water demand, age and species and invites all citizens to participate in the irrigation of our endangered tree population. Citizens can inform themselves about the water demand of trees in their neighbourhood, mark when they have watered and how much and "subscribe" to trees.

gsx$contentblockone.$t:
Overview of the Berlin tree population: 625,000 Berlin street and plant trees are visualized on an interactive map.

Exploration of the tree population: For each tree, information on type, age and estimated required water quantity is stored, so that more can be learned about each tree with the help of search and filter functions.

Watering and subscribing to trees: The platform shows which trees need how much water, depending on their age and urban maintenance. Users* can indicate when they last watered a tree. Trees can also be subscribed to if someone wants to water them regularly. This allows other people in the vicinity to see which trees need their attention.

Precipitation overview: With the help of daily updated data from the German Weather Service, it is possible to display for each tree how much rainwater it has received in the last 30 days.

Further information: In addition, the platform contains a wealth of useful information on correct irrigation and tree population, as well as relevant links and contact addresses.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: You can simply register, water and mark the irrigation online. In addition, we will collect feedback over the next few months and consider further development of the first prototype. For the exchange with us and other interested people there is a public Slack channel

gsx$contentblockthree.$t:
Mirko Hohmann
Giessdenkiez.de
Slack channel

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: internetoftrees, projectname: Internet der Bäume, projectsubline: CityLAB (A Technologiestiftung Berlin Project), headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Berlin's city trees suffer from severe drought, which endangers the entire Berlin ecosystem in the long term. In the project "Internet of Trees" we develop digital strategies and prototypes to strengthen Berlin's tree population. Among other things, we are working on a humidity sensor based on LoRa, which sounds the alarm during drought, and on an online platform via which citizens* can participate and coordinate in the irrigation of trees., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: In the CityLAB workshop we are working on improving the sensor, making it smaller and more durable. At the same time, a first prototype of a web application is being developed at internetoftrees.citylab-berlin.org. In addition to an interactive representation of the tree register, further data, such as rainfall and soil moisture, are to be integrated here in the future. In future iterations, it will be possible to subscribe to individual trees and to receive information via e-mail or Twitter, for example, if a tree has not received water for a longer period of time. In the medium term, a test of the system in a delimited network of trees is planned, with the help of which further qualitative data on the condition of the trees can be collected., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: The sensor team meets regularly in the CityLAB workshop and is looking forward to support in prototyping. Hardware for handicrafts is available! You can also borrow a sensor and test it on a tree in your yard or garden. The code for our web application is of course Open Source and is looking forward to your contributions (GitHub)., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Mirko Hohmann, Sara Reichert, logo: FALSE

gsx$contentintro.$t: Berlin's city trees suffer from severe drought, which endangers the entire Berlin ecosystem in the long term. In the project "Internet of Trees" we develop digital strategies and prototypes to strengthen Berlin's tree population. Among other things, we are working on a humidity sensor based on LoRa, which sounds the alarm during drought, and on an online platform via which citizens* can participate and coordinate in the irrigation of trees.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: In the CityLAB workshop we are working on improving the sensor, making it smaller and more durable. At the same time, a first prototype of a web application is being developed at internetoftrees.citylab-berlin.org. In addition to an interactive representation of the tree register, further data, such as rainfall and soil moisture, are to be integrated here in the future. In future iterations, it will be possible to subscribe to individual trees and to receive information via e-mail or Twitter, for example, if a tree has not received water for a longer period of time. In the medium term, a test of the system in a delimited network of trees is planned, with the help of which further qualitative data on the condition of the trees can be collected.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: The sensor team meets regularly in the CityLAB workshop and is looking forward to support in prototyping. Hardware for handicrafts is available! You can also borrow a sensor and test it on a tree in your yard or garden. The code for our web application is of course Open Source and is looking forward to your contributions (GitHub).

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Mirko Hohmann, Sara Reichert

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: Senatsverwaltung für Umwelt, Verkehr und Klimaschutz, dirname: pari, projectname: Prozessanalyse Radinfrastruktur (PARI), projectsubline: Senatsverwaltung für Umwelt, Verkehr und Klimaschutz, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Cycling is good for the climate, against traffic jams and for clean air. For this reason, many new cycle paths are to be built on the basis of the new Berlin Mobility Act. However, the administrative procedures are not yet designed to shape this change quickly. We want to change that., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: We analyse the processes and procedures that are currently being used to work on the Berlin cycling infrastructure. Who has to agree to what? What are the deadlines? In short: why does it take so long? Does that have to be the case? How can we achieve better results faster and become more transparent?, headlineblocktwo: Who is involved?, contentblocktwo: PARI is a project that will initially be carried out with various administrations and CityLAB. The aim is to achieve more transparent and faster procedures, which we are constantly improving with the help of experts., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Peter Feldkamp, Koordinierungsstelle Radverkehr, link: https://www.berlin.de/sen/uvk/, logo: FALSE

gsx$publisher.$t: Senatsverwaltung für Umwelt, Verkehr und Klimaschutz

gsx$projectsubline.$t: Senatsverwaltung für Umwelt, Verkehr und Klimaschutz

gsx$contentintro.$t: Cycling is good for the climate, against traffic jams and for clean air. For this reason, many new cycle paths are to be built on the basis of the new Berlin Mobility Act. However, the administrative procedures are not yet designed to shape this change quickly. We want to change that.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: We analyse the processes and procedures that are currently being used to work on the Berlin cycling infrastructure. Who has to agree to what? What are the deadlines? In short: why does it take so long? Does that have to be the case? How can we achieve better results faster and become more transparent?

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: PARI is a project that will initially be carried out with various administrations and CityLAB. The aim is to achieve more transparent and faster procedures, which we are constantly improving with the help of experts.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Peter Feldkamp, Koordinierungsstelle Radverkehr

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, publisher: Senatsverwaltung für Umwelt, Verkehr und Klimaschutz, dirname: crossings, projectname: Neues Kreuzungs­design für Berlin, projectsubline: SenUVK, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Berlin has committed itself to Vision Zero. No one shall be seriously injured or die in Berlin's traffic. Most serious accidents happen at intersections. We therefore want to make intersections safer for weaker road users* in pedestrian and cycle traffic!, headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: Together with experts from our bicycle-friendly neighbouring country Holland, we take a look at Berlin intersections and find out what we can learn from the Netherlands. We create concrete designs and plan the procedures to implement them., headlineblocktwo: Who's involved?, contentblocktwo: Crossings do not have to please the planners, but function for the people who use them. That is why we will present our designs here and discuss and evaluate them with you., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Peter Feldkamp, Koordinierungsstelle Radverkehr, peter.feldkamp@senuvk.berlin.de, link: https://www.berlin.de/sen/uvk/, logo: FALSE

gsx$publisher.$t: Senatsverwaltung für Umwelt, Verkehr und Klimaschutz

gsx$contentintro.$t: Berlin has committed itself to Vision Zero. No one shall be seriously injured or die in Berlin's traffic. Most serious accidents happen at intersections. We therefore want to make intersections safer for weaker road users* in pedestrian and cycle traffic!

gsx$contentblockone.$t: Together with experts from our bicycle-friendly neighbouring country Holland, we take a look at Berlin intersections and find out what we can learn from the Netherlands. We create concrete designs and plan the procedures to implement them.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Crossings do not have to please the planners, but function for the people who use them. That is why we will present our designs here and discuss and evaluate them with you.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Peter Feldkamp, Koordinierungsstelle Radverkehr, peter.feldkamp@senuvk.berlin.de

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: TRUE, publisher: Open Data Informationsstelle, dirname: districtprofiles, projectname: Bezirksregionen digital, projectsubline: ODIS/Senatsverwaltung für Wirtschaft, Energie und Betriebe/BA Tempelhof-Schöneberg, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: The Berlin districts publish regular reports on the socio-economic situation of their district regions ("Bezirksregionenprofile"). These reports contain relevant information and data - but in long, unwieldy PDF documents. We are building a tool that presents these reports interactively and makes the underlying data more accessible for further use., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: The team of the Open Data Informationsstelle has developed a prototype which is now being tested together with the data coordination of the district office Tempelhof-Schöneberg. The prototype is fed with real data and at the same time tested for its usability., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: The code of the tool is open source and can be found on GitHub - anyone can use it further or make suggestions for improvements. If you are interested to try the tool and give us feedback, feel free to contact us anytime!, headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Victoria Boeck , link: http://odis-berlin.de/, logo: FALSE

gsx$projectsubline.$t: ODIS/Senatsverwaltung für Wirtschaft, Energie und Betriebe/BA Tempelhof-Schöneberg

gsx$contentintro.$t: The Berlin districts publish regular reports on the socio-economic situation of their district regions ("Bezirksregionenprofile"). These reports contain relevant information and data - but in long, unwieldy PDF documents. We are building a tool that presents these reports interactively and makes the underlying data more accessible for further use.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: The team of the Open Data Informationsstelle has developed a prototype which is now being tested together with the data coordination of the district office Tempelhof-Schöneberg. The prototype is fed with real data and at the same time tested for its usability.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: The code of the tool is open source and can be found on GitHub - anyone can use it further or make suggestions for improvements. If you are interested to try the tool and give us feedback, feel free to contact us anytime!

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Victoria Boeck

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: Fraunhofer FOKUS, dirname: kiezradar, projectname: KiezRadar, projectsubline: Fraunhofer FOKUS, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Instead of digging its way through Berlin's digital offerings, the Kiez radar app will proactively inform citizens about important political and administrative events in the future. This should make participation as simple as possible., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: Relevant application scenarios and requirements for the KiezRadar app will be determined together with the future users*. In the CityLAB Berlin different operating and communication concepts will be tested on prototypes. In the end, an executable beta version is to be developed., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: In the course of the project, various participatory workshops will take place at CityLAB Berlin, at which we will discuss with citizens* their wishes, goals or expectations of such an app and jointly develop initial proposals for solutions and visions. The workshop dates are communicated regularly on the CityLAB events page., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Susanna Kuper , link: https://www.fokus.fraunhofer.de, logo: FALSE

gsx$contentintro.$t: Instead of digging its way through Berlin's digital offerings, the Kiez radar app will proactively inform citizens about important political and administrative events in the future. This should make participation as simple as possible.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: Relevant application scenarios and requirements for the KiezRadar app will be determined together with the future users*. In the CityLAB Berlin different operating and communication concepts will be tested on prototypes. In the end, an executable beta version is to be developed.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: In the course of the project, various participatory workshops will take place at CityLAB Berlin, at which we will discuss with citizens* their wishes, goals or expectations of such an app and jointly develop initial proposals for solutions and visions. The workshop dates are communicated regularly on the CityLAB events page.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Susanna Kuper

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: FixMyBerlin, dirname: meldefuchs, projectname: Meldefuchs, projectsubline: FixMyBerlin, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: To improve communication between administration and citizens*, FixMyBerlin is developing reporting dialogues that give citizens* the opportunity to give feedback or report needs on clear, pointed questions in 30 seconds using WebApp. The reports are checked by the administration and the result is reported back to the citizens* via FixMyBerlin., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: An initial dialogue on the reporting of bicycle brackets has already been developed. In the CityLAB FixMyBerlin organizes workshops on questions for further dialogues. The dialogues will then gradually be carried out together with the Berlin administration., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: You are cordially invited to participate in one of the workshops on new questions and topics. We are also always happy about free developers* who want to improve and further develop the code., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Melde Dich unter hello@fixmyberlin.de, oder trage Dich auf fixmyberlin.de in unseren Newsletter ein. Hier im CityLAB findest du uns im Co-Working Space., link: https://fixmyberlin.de/, logo: TRUE

gsx$contentintro.$t: To improve communication between administration and citizens*, FixMyBerlin is developing reporting dialogues that give citizens* the opportunity to give feedback or report needs on clear, pointed questions in 30 seconds using WebApp. The reports are checked by the administration and the result is reported back to the citizens* via FixMyBerlin.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: An initial dialogue on the reporting of bicycle brackets has already been developed. In the CityLAB FixMyBerlin organizes workshops on questions for further dialogues. The dialogues will then gradually be carried out together with the Berlin administration.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: You are cordially invited to participate in one of the workshops on new questions and topics. We are also always happy about free developers* who want to improve and further develop the code.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Melde Dich unter hello@fixmyberlin.de, oder trage Dich auf fixmyberlin.de in unseren Newsletter ein. Hier im CityLAB findest du uns im Co-Working Space.

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: TU Berlin StadtManufaktur, dirname: lastmile, projectname: Last Mile, projectsubline: TU Berlin StadtManufaktur, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: "The StadtManufaktur is an initiative of the Technical University of Berlin. Its aim is to solve complex urban challenges by combining science and practice. In the projects, scientists* work together with city stakeholders to develop forward-looking solutions for Berlin. Our initial project is "Last Mile - New Neighbourhood".", headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: The project "Last Mile - New Neighbourhood" will focus on the interlinking of housing and mobility data. The aim is to develop new neighbourhood concepts in Neu-Hohenschönhausen. In interdisciplinary teams, the concepts are to be developed in a participatory manner with civil society., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: The StadtManufaktur is an offer to the urban society to be available in the long term as a partner for complex urban transformation processes. Together with residents*, politicians and administrators, local companies and municipal utilities, we want to initiate and support project-specific cooperation., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Audrey Podann, audrey.podann@tu-berlin.de Gabriele Wendorf, wendorf@ztg.tu-berlin.de Jochen Rabe, rabe@tu-berlin.de, link: https://www.berlin.de/sen/uvk/, logo: FALSE

gsx$contentintro.$t: "The StadtManufaktur is an initiative of the Technical University of Berlin. Its aim is to solve complex urban challenges by combining science and practice. In the projects, scientists* work together with city stakeholders to develop forward-looking solutions for Berlin. Our initial project is "Last Mile - New Neighbourhood"."

gsx$contentblockone.$t: The project "Last Mile - New Neighbourhood" will focus on the interlinking of housing and mobility data. The aim is to develop new neighbourhood concepts in Neu-Hohenschönhausen. In interdisciplinary teams, the concepts are to be developed in a participatory manner with civil society.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: The StadtManufaktur is an offer to the urban society to be available in the long term as a partner for complex urban transformation processes. Together with residents*, politicians and administrators, local companies and municipal utilities, we want to initiate and support project-specific cooperation.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Audrey Podann, audrey.podann@tu-berlin.de Gabriele Wendorf, wendorf@ztg.tu-berlin.de Jochen Rabe, rabe@tu-berlin.de

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: GGSt BSO, dirname: GGStBSO, projectname: Gem. Geschäftsstelle Schulbauoffensive Berliner Bezirke, projectsubline: Gem. Geschäftsstelle Schulbauoffensive Berliner Bezirke, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: The Joint Office School Construction Offensive of the Berlin Districts (GGSt BSO) was founded together with three regional associations in order to strategically support the Berlin districts within the framework of the school construction offensive and to accompany processes. The aim is to use the new form of supra-regional cooperation to bundle existing competencies and create synergy effects., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: These newly created organisational units are intended to strengthen supra-regional coordination and speed up procedures. Planned measures include the establishment of a joint network, the organisation of exchanges of experience and information events, the monitoring of participation procedures and supporting measures to recruit personnel and standardise data structures., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: Modern school construction requires an agile administration with new ways of cooperation within the administration and opening up to the outside world. The GGSt BSO is a central point of contact and offers cross-cutting services for the administration. Suggestions and ideas for initiatives are welcome and are gladly passed on to the right people., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: InfoGGStBSO@bezirksamt-neukoelln.de https://www.berlin.de/schulbau/bezirke, link: https://berlin.de, logo: FALSE

gsx$contentintro.$t: The Joint Office School Construction Offensive of the Berlin Districts (GGSt BSO) was founded together with three regional associations in order to strategically support the Berlin districts within the framework of the school construction offensive and to accompany processes. The aim is to use the new form of supra-regional cooperation to bundle existing competencies and create synergy effects.

gsx$contentblockone.$t: These newly created organisational units are intended to strengthen supra-regional coordination and speed up procedures. Planned measures include the establishment of a joint network, the organisation of exchanges of experience and information events, the monitoring of participation procedures and supporting measures to recruit personnel and standardise data structures.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Modern school construction requires an agile administration with new ways of cooperation within the administration and opening up to the outside world. The GGSt BSO is a central point of contact and offers cross-cutting services for the administration. Suggestions and ideas for initiatives are welcome and are gladly passed on to the right people.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: InfoGGStBSO@bezirksamt-neukoelln.de https://www.berlin.de/schulbau/bezirke

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: Technologiestiftung Berlin, dirname: hardwareflohmarkt, projectname: Hardware-Flohmarkt 2.0 Berlin, projectsubline: Technologiestiftung Berlin, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Who doesn't know it - after the spring cleaning in the hardware cabinet there is a box with wonderful components that are no longer needed. And for upcoming projects something new has to be found quickly - but please sustainable! For this we would like to offer a platform to all eager doers and exchange information about Upcycling, Repairing & Co!, headlineblockone: What happened so far?, contentblockone: After our joint warm-up at the end of June we started directly with the first flea market date - on 8 September it took place for the first time at CityLAB Berlin. Hardware flea market in connection with a panel on sustainable Berlin projects in the field of recycling management and recycling. As the first event for community and civil society at CityLAB, we were also able to welcome new visitors* to the Open Monument Day. , headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: What is certain is that the topic definitely belongs in an innovation laboratory for the city of the future, as CityLAB is. It became clear that this event has potential - we continue to invite the community to further develop the format together with us! Please do not hesitate to contact us!, headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Carolin Clausnitzer, clausnitzer@technologiestiftung-berlin.de, link: https://technologiestiftung-berlin.de, logo: FALSE

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: innovationskompass, projectname: Innovationskompass für die öffentliche Verwaltung, projectsubline: Politics for Tomorrow, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: How does innovation actually work in public administration? At CityLAB, Politics for Tomorrow is working on the development of an innovation compass for the public sector in German-speaking countries. The Innovation Compass is based on a combination of statistical surveys and reflexive self-assessment by administrative staff to find out how new impulses can be set in the public sector., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: The Innovation Compass survey of public administration in Germany, Switzerland and Austria was launched. The feedback is currently being evaluated and processed in workshops. The results are to be used as part of the CityLAB innovation offer for the Berlin administration. , headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: The Innovation Compass survey is aimed at employees at all levels of government and administration in German-speaking countries. The questionnaire can be completed within 15 to 30 minutes, either alone or as part of a team, and can be reached below the link., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Caroline Paulick-Thiel , link: https://www.innovationskompass.net/mitmachen.html

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: stadtvisionen, projectname: Algorithmische Stadtvisionen, projectsubline: CityLAB (A Technologiestiftung Berlin Project)/Birds on Mars, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: How the city of the future will look can also be tested with the help of intelligent systems: The city vision project uses artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning for architecture and urban planning. A neural network is trained with the help of a self-generated data set from around 10,000 city maps. On this basis, the AI system creates its own fictitious city designs., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: The first city visions developed are already being visualized using a hardware plotter in the CityLAB exhibition. Currently, further training of the network and the parallel development of a screen-based application is taking place. Through an interactive interface, the abstract topic of artificial intelligence is to be experienced by visitors., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: CityLAB and Birds on Mars organize a regular "AI for Berlin" workshop series to put concrete ideas on AI and city into practice. From brainstorming and conception to prototyping, design and implementation, intelligent solutions for Berlin are worked on in individual sessions in interdisciplinary and open teams. No matter whether you already have a concrete idea that you would like to contribute, are Python enthusiastic or simply want to take the opportunity to experience the pulse of time as an enthusiast* - the sessions are open to everyone and will be announced on the CityLAB website., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Fabian Morón Zirfas, Florian Dohmann (Birds on Mars)

gsx$projectsubline.$t: CityLAB (A Technologiestiftung Berlin Project)/Birds on Mars

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: startupmapping, projectname: Berlin Urban Tech-Datenbank, projectsubline: Urban Impact, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Urban Impact networks startups and innovators in the field of urban technology with urban players and investors throughout Europe in order to implement and scale good solutions for sustainable cities more quickly. The CityLAB is working on a database of Berlin Urban Tech and Smart City Start-Ups in order to give the Berlin administration a better overview and to improve the networking of the Berlin actors., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: Quantitative analyses of the startup scene in Berlin are currently being prepared for the database, which will be supplemented by a qualitative assessment in the next step. In addition, Urban Impact supports the networking of the Urban Tech and CityLAB communities, e.g. by integrating them into hackathons. , headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: No matter if startup or city administration - we are looking forward to all interested parties and innovators* for sustainable Urban Tech solutions, which we can integrate into the emerging network and connect with each other. , headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Jonas Schorr, Urban Impact

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: TRUE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: trafficcount, projectname: Open Traffic Count, projectsubline: Moove Labs, HTW Berlin, Technologiestiftung Berlin, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: Counting cars, bicycles and pedestrians in traffic in real time, at low cost and in compliance with strict data protection regulations - newer methods of machine learning make this possible. However, empirically valid and meaningful evaluations of such systems in everyday urban life are still lacking. With a grant from the BMVI mFund, OpenTrafficCount would like to test the application of a counting system developed from open source components at various locations in the Berlin city area., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: As part of the CityLAB Summer School, a first prototype of an AI-based real-time camera was successfully tested together with students from the Berlin University of Applied Sciences. We are currently looking for test locations to test the system in real operation under various weather and lighting conditions. , headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: We are constantly looking for test locations and other applications. If you have interesting scenarios for testing traffic or pedestrian counts that comply with data protection regulations, please contact us. In addition, we regularly conduct design sprints in which new use cases are devised. The source code for the Open Data Cam can be found here., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Dr. Sebastian Meier

gsx$projectsubline.$t: Moove Labs, HTW Berlin, Technologiestiftung Berlin

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: radverkehrsplanung, projectname: Digitale Tools für Radwegeplanung, projectsubline: FixMyBerlin, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: FixMyBerlin accompanies the Berlin administration in the implementation of the mobility law and develops digital tools for bicycle traffic planning. The aim of the project is to create a data-based basis for a constructive dialogue between the administration and citizens. For this purpose, the current bicycle traffic planning is displayed on an online map and participation formats for the constructive integration of citizens are developed., headlineblockone: Next steps?, contentblockone: In September 2019, the online registration dialogue for new bicycle hangers was publicly presented as a cooperation with the Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg district office. By mid-October, around 1,200 reports had been received, which are now being checked and implemented by the administration. In November, a survey on the subjective safety of bicycle infrastructure was launched in cooperation with the Tagesspiegel newspaper., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: CityLAB regularly hosts a "Data Cycle MeetUp" organized by FixMyBerlin. All interested parties are welcome to participate and thus to participate in the project., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Register at hello@fixmyberlin.de, or sign up for the newsletter at fixmyberlin.de. In CityLAB you can find us in the Co-Working Space. , link: https://www.meetup.com/de-DE/Datacycle-Meetup-Fahrraddaten-fur-Berlin/

defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: Technologiestiftung Berlin, dirname: werkstatt, projectname: Werkstatt im CityLAB, projectsubline: Technologiestiftung Berlin, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: The "Workshop in CityLAB" is a space for experiments with methods from the colour palette of electrical engineering and computer science - and everything else that appeals to your creativity. All activities are thematically related to current digital urban issues and are complemented by the production of freely licensed educational materials. The focus is on a participative and inclusive mediation work. All citizens of the city are invited to create the future of the city with coding and hardware "hands on"., headlineblockone: What happened so far?, contentblockone: Every last Friday of the month from 2 pm to 6 pm, the creators of the "Werkstatt im CityLAB" invite you to an open workshop afternoon with different focus topics. In July 2019 it opened its doors for the first time - on the topic of upcycling! Followed by further workshops, for example for the construction of a GPS tracker, digital street music, bicycle lighting and automated allotment garden paradises for the windowsill at home. In addition, workshops and projects in cooperation with external partners such as the HTW Berlin, the Fliegerwerkstatt or the LoRaWAN community (local radio applications in the IoT area) are being developed in the workshop., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: Current events of the "Werkstatt im CityLAB" can be found in the event calendars of the Technology Foundation and CityLAB. We are looking forward to all who come and participate! We regularly document the results on the Technology Foundation's blog and on Github.

. Previous knowledge is not necessary. We are happy about everyone who comes and participates!

With the workshop in CityLAB, the Technology Foundation Berlin makes an offer to the city's citizens* to cooperate on exemplary projects in education and empowerment in CityLAB and to communicate the content to the outside world in the form of events, freely licensed educational materials and through implementation in the urban space.

, headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Team Digital Education: Dr. Dieter Müller, Carolin Clausnitzer, Sara Reichert, link: https://github.com/technologiestiftung/werkstatt

defaultimg: FALSE, featured: TRUE, publisher: Technologiestiftung Berlin, dirname: prototype, projectname: Prototype Your Future City!, projectsubline: Technologiestiftung Berlin, HTW Berlin, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: During a three-day interdisciplinary workshop, students of the HTW Berlin work on their own personal ideas for their Berlin of the future. How do we want to live in the city in the future? What would we like to change in our immediate surroundings? Are there any international examples from which Berlin can still learn? These very personal visions of the future of the city will be implemented by the participants* under the guidance of mentors* in the form of prototypes., headlineblockone: What's the background?, contentblockone: Every last Friday of the month from 2 pm to 6 pm, the creators of the "Werkstatt im CityLAB" invite you to an open workshop afternoon with different focus topics. In July 2019 it opened its doors for the first time - on the topic of upcycling! This was followed by further dates, for example for the construction of a GPS tracker, digital street music, bicycle lighting and automated allotment garden paradises for the windowsill at home. In addition, workshops and projects in cooperation with external partners such as the HTW Berlin, the aviation workshop or the LoRaWAN community (local radio applications in the IoT area) are being developed in the workshop., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: With the "Workshop in CityLAB", the Technologiestiftung Berlin is making an offer to the citizens of Berlin to work together on exemplary projects in education and empowerment in CityLAB and to disseminate the contents to the outside world in the form of events, freely licensed educational materials and through implementation in urban space.

, headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Carolin Clausnitzer

defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: 1-AD is the digital first aid for discrimination. Through a chatbot, people affected by discrimination can inform themselves about their rights, report incidents and find advice near them at any time of the day. Availability via mobile phone lowers the threshold of reluctance to seek advice and offers a possible answer to the high number of unreported incidents., headlineblockone: What happened so far?, contentblockone: At the Hackathon "Hack 4 Justice" in June 2019, innovative concepts were developed that offer promising approaches to bring anti-discrimination counselling into the digital age. "1-AD" is a summary of these approaches. The next step is to develop a prototype and secure funding., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: The first workshops took place in cooperation with the HTW Berlin as part of the Code Week at CityLAB. Currently, the students continue to implement the prototypical developments within the framework of the seminar with Dr. Beatrice Moreno at the HTW. Be sure to mark them in your calendar: On 15 January 2020, the final presentation will take place at CityLAB!, headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Said Haider
said.haider@gmail.com

content.$t: defaultimg: FALSE, featured: FALSE, publisher: Technologiestiftung Berlin, dirname: conversational, projectname: Conversational Interfaces, projectsubline: CityLAB (A Technologiestiftung Berlin Project), headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: The digitization of public tasks and services is still strongly oriented towards analog processes - a digitized form, for example, often does not differ from those we find in paper form in authorities. In the digital world, however, we are used to other processes: With language assistants and messenger services, conversations are the focus. Public authorities and other interactions between citizens* and the administration can be made much easier and more intelligent with the help of so-called conversational interfaces such as chatbots. , headlineblockone: What's your plan?, contentblockone: We are developing an open source library to make it easier for administrations and other organizations to use chatbot systems, for example in the area of initial consultations. Using selected use cases, we want to test the tool together with administrative employees and citizens* in order to find out where chatbots can offer real added value compared to conventional information offerings or forms. In addition, integration possibilities with various messenger systems (WhatsApp, Telegram, etc.) will be tested., headlineblocktwo: How can I join in?, contentblocktwo: Above all, we need support in the preparation of data and decision trees. If you have ideas for applications where the use of chatbots could be useful, come by and join us. A kick-off workshop is scheduled for early 2020 and will be communicated via our website., headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Sina Beckstein

Public authorities and other interactions between citizens* and the administration can be made much easier and more intelligent with the help of so-called conversational interfaces such as chatbots.

Using selected use cases, we want to test the tool together with administrative employees and citizens* in order to find out where chatbots can offer real added value compared to conventional information offerings or forms. In addition, integration possibilities with various messenger systems (WhatsApp, Telegram, etc.) will be tested.

gsx$contentblocktwo.$t: Above all, we need support in the preparation of data and decision trees. If you have ideas for applications where the use of chatbots could be useful, come by and join us. A kick-off workshop is scheduled for early 2020 and will be communicated via our website.

gsx$contentblockthree.$t: Sina Beckstein

content.$t:
defaultimg: FALSE, featured: TRUE, publisher: CityLAB Berlin, dirname: bikesharing, projectname: Shared Mobility Flows, projectsubline: CityLAB (A Technologiestiftung Berlin Project), headlineintro: What's the point?, contentintro: More and more mobility sharing providers (rental bikes, e-scooters, etc.) are present on Berlin's streets. This presents the city with new challenges, but also opens up opportunities: in addition to a broader range of mobility services, the data from the sharing providers can provide valuable insights for administration and urban planning and enable more intelligent traffic planning. In the "Shared Mobility Flows" project, we developed data standards for sharing services and a digital prototype that analyzes and visualizes rental bike routes on a map. , headlineblockone: How did you go about it?, contentblockone: In a workshop, we brought together around 20 participants* from business, science, politics and administration to present the internationally increasingly widespread "Mobility Data Specitifcation" (MDS) and to discuss its possible applications. For Berlin, uniform data standards in the mobility sector would be an important step towards making existing data usable. With our online prototype, we are demonstrating how real data from sharing providers can be used to gain interesting insights into individual mobility. The prototype was further developed together with district planners and supplemented with concrete scenarios. , headlineblocktwo: Results, contentblocktwo: Prototype: http://bikesharing.citylab-berlin.org/

Source Code of the data visualization:
https://github.com/technologiestiftung/bikesharing-vis
Source Code to the Data script
https://github.com/technologiestiftung/bike-sharing
, headlineblockthree: Contact:, contentblockthree: Fabian Dinklage

In the "Shared Mobility Flows" project, we developed data standards for sharing services and a digital prototype that analyzes and visualizes rental bike routes on a map.

For Berlin, uniform data standards in the mobility sector would be an important step towards making existing data usable. With our online prototype, we are demonstrating how real data from sharing providers can be used to gain interesting insights into individual mobility. The prototype was further developed together with district planners and supplemented with concrete scenarios.
